title: Worldwise: Ennismore CEO Sharan Pasricha’s Favorite Things
text:
Text size

Overseeing the hospitality group that operates The Hoxton hotels, Ennismore Founder and CEO Sharan Pasricha is at the helm of one of today’s most relevant hotel brands.

He bought the original Hoxton in London’s Shoreditch neighborhood in 2012, followed by openings in Amsterdam and Paris. Ennismore now has nine Hoxton properties across Europe and the U.S., alongside the notable Gleneagles golf resort in the Scottish Highlands, a new co-working concept, and several other projects on the horizon.

Penta caught up with the 38-year-old, Indian-born entrepreneur to learn more about what stands out for him in terms of travel, and where he likes to go when he’s home in West London.

My favorite neighborhood in the world is... tough question—I’ll always have a soft spot for Shoreditch in East London. It’s where it all started for The Hoxton back in the day, and I spent a year doing every role you can imagine in the hotel and restaurant business. Shoreditch is just as much a buzzy and evolving neighborhood now as it was back then. There’s a great energy to it, a tight creative community, and it’s by far one of the most exciting neighborhoods to eat in London—you’ve got Michelin-star spots next to cult street food favorites and old school institutions.

The one thing in my closet I can't live without is... I’m a sucker for comfort; whether I’m in the office or traveling, you’ll often find me in a hoodie and Nike high tops. Suits are overrated.

If I were to buy a piece of art, it would be by... I’ve always loved Yoshitomo Nara. Nara’s figures have become instantly recognizable, and his works from the early 2000s are not only my favorite, but considered some of his most important. They would hang beautifully in my living room!

The best book I’ve read in the last year is… I don’t get as much time to read as I’d like but I really enjoyed Matt Haig ’s How To Stay Alive. It’s extremely thought provoking, yet funny. He’s a brilliant writer. Next on my list is The Subtle Art of Not Giving a F---,by Mark Manson.

A passion of mine that few people know about is... I’m quietly getting into track racing actually, though I wouldn’t say I’m any good at it. But whenever I get the chance, I will try and rent a car and get on a racetrack. The Porsche Experience Center in L.A. is one of my favorite days out.

The one trip I’ve taken that I would love to do again… I would love to go back to the rainforests of Rwanda to see the gorillas. Nothing quite compares like having to stand still as a 350-pound Silverback brushes by you.

The next destination on my travel itinerary is… I’m looking forward to really getting under the skin of California, as I’ll be spending more time that way with the opening of The Hoxton, Downtown L.A. in October. L.A. never gets old to me—those West Coast vibes are always a nice change from London! Top of my hit list on this trip is dinner at Bestia–I’ve heard very good things about the truffle cavatelli! In Downtown L.A., I always swing by Bodega to pick up a new pair of kicks (or two).

The thing that gets me up in the morning is… my trainer. That’s because he won’t let me sleep past 6:30 a.m. without a phone call.

The restaurant/bar in my hometown that I love to take a visitor is… I live in West London and there’s quite a lot going on my way at the moment. Gold in Notting Hill is a new favorite—it’s got stunning interiors, great, simple dishes, and a brilliant natural wine list. As for something a bit more casual, I go to EGGBREAK with my family pretty much every weekend I’m in town. Everyone needs to try their Nutella Stuffed French Toast.

A person who inspired me to do what I do is… in terms of moving me to delve into the world of hospitality, it’s tricky to pick one specific source of inspiration because it combines so many of my passions ranging from architecture to brand and storytelling. I have also admired Jeff Bezos for his audacity to innovate at scale and disrupt not one but several industries at the same time.

If I could have a drink with anybody, anywhere, it would be… I’d love to split a strong drink with Chris Blackwell at The American Bar at Gleneagles and ask him about his vision behind Goldeneye, the Jamaican resort built around novelist Ian Fleming’s former villa and the birthplace of the James Bond books.
description: The hotel innovator keeps things casual on either side of the Atlantic
